Comment: This old-fashioned opening exposes White's Queen to Black's pieces. Black tends to gain an advantage in development as a result.

This old-fashioned opening exposes White's Queen to Black's pieces. Black tends to gain an advantage in development as a result.
Developing the Knight to its natural square and gaining a tempo.
Now Black can develop his King Knight as well. He has 2 pieces out and White only has 1.

Overly aggressive. White does need to develop, but a more modest move such as B-Q3 or N-QB3 [both of which also defend the exposed KP] would serve him better. Because of the premature Queen development, White is on the defensive.
Swiderski takes advantage of White's mistake, centralizing his Knight and attacking the unprotected KB.
White's Bishop is forced to retreat...
...allowing Swiderski time to develop another piece with tempo. White needs to develop and break the attack. 7 N-QB3 or 7 N-Q2 is in order.
A major blunder by White. Not only does this not develop a piece, it also blocks his QN from its natural square!

Swiderski pounces, attacking the Queen again. Obviously White cannot play 8 QxB??? as 8...N-Q6 ch!!! would fork White's King and Queen. Probably the "best" move is 8 Q-K2, although even then White would be in trouble, massively behind in development.
The second blunder in a row allows Swiderski a brilliant finish.

Forking King and Queen. If 9 QxB, 9...N-Q6 ch forks the royalty again. If 9 KxB, 9...NxP ch ALSO forks the white royals! White does the honorable thing and resigns. He has been magnificently outplayed!
